block.p: ITALY: ELECTION REFORM VOTE -- The constitutional court gave the go-ahead to seven referendums between April and June, including one that its supporters say would end political instability by abolishing election by proportional representation to a quarter of the seats in Parliament's 630-member lower house. In a vote last April, some 90 percent favored doing away with proportional representation. But the ballot was declared void when the turnout reached only 49.6 percent.

FRANCE: FIVE BASQUES SEIZED -- The police arrested Juan Carlos Iglesias Chouzas, 36, considered a top commander of the Basque separatist group E.T.A., and four other suspected Basque separatists in a two-day sweep. It came just days after Spain detained eight people, including four leftist politicians, on charges of providing logistical aid to the rebels. The Spanish government holds E.T.A. rebels responsible for a bombing in Madrid that killed an army officer.

FINLAND: CONSERVATIVE SURGES -- Support has surged for Esko Aho, the conservative candidate in the presidential vote on Sunday, and polls put him in a dead heat with a liberal seeking to become the first woman to be head of state. A survey of more than 1,400 voters gave Mr. Aho, of the conservative Center Party, a 49 percent rating, a big increase from results in two polls after the first round vote on Jan. 16. The same poll, with a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percentage points, put support for Foreign Minister Tarja Halonen of the Social Democrats at 51 percent, down sharply.

GREECE: TURK VISITS -- Ismail Cem, the first Turkish foreign minister to visit Greece in 40 years, arrived in Athens to sign five accords and discuss the next steps for easing tensions between Greece and Turkey. During his three-day stay, Mr. Cem will try to persuade Greece to endorse joint military maneuvers.

MEXICO: GOVERNOR FACES TRIAL -- The Supreme Court approved an impeachment trial of Gov. Jorge Carrillo Olea of Morelos, who took a leave of absence in May 1998 after two top aides were jailed in connection with the torture death of a kidnapping suspect. The Morelos legislature voted to impeach him last June, but the top state court said governors could not be put on trial.

COLOMBIA: SWEDISH PEACE TALKS -- Leaders of Colombia's main rebel force and government officials arrived in Stockholm to hold peace talks and to study Scandinavia's socioeconomic system. The Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia commanders are meeting with government officials on a Swedish-sponsored trip as part of a plan to end Colombia's four-decades-old conflict.

ARGENTINA: TAX FRAUD DRIVE -- President Fernando de la Rua showed his determination for cracking down on tax fraud by starting a sweeping sting operation in which 72 tax officials coordinated raids on various businesses to find workers who are off the books and do not pay income tax. An estimated $20 billion a year is lost in taxes due to fraud.

AFRICA -- SOUTH AFRICA: SECURITY ALERT -- Security was expected to be stepped up for President Thabo Mbeki's address to the opening session of Parliament in Cape Town today. Bombings have plagued the seaside city during the last few years, including a spate of attacks in the last few months.

KENYA: EMBASSY MEMORIAL -- The site of the United States Embassy destroyed by a terrorist bomb will be turned into a memorial park dedicated to the 213 people killed in the blast, the embassy said. The building was demolished last year after the Aug. 7, 1998, bombing.

IRAQ: U.S. JETS ATTACK -- American planes bombed an Iraqi air defense system in response to artillery fire as they patrolled a no-flight zone over northern Iraq, the United States European Command said. The bombing was the eighth in northern Iraq this year.

INDIA: KARMAPA LEADS PRAYERS -- Ugyen Trinley Dorje, the 14-year-old Karmapa who arrived in India this year after escaping from China, led a five-minute prayer session at the Gyodo Monastery in Dharamsala, home of Tibet's government-in-exile. Indian paramilitary troops were stationed around the grounds and visitors had to pass through two separate security checks.

PAKISTAN: KASHMIR HOLIDAY -- The military rulers have declared Saturday a public holiday in solidarity with militants fighting in Indian-controlled Kashmir. Rallies are planned and all government offices, banks and businesses will be closed. The Harkat-ul-Mujahedeen group said it would celebrate by stepping up attacks, to ''send gifts of bodies to Indian oppressor beasts.''

BANGLADESH: STRIKES' TOLL -- As the nation was paralyzed by a second day of political strikes, the Bangladesh Road Transport Authority reported that such commonplace work stoppages cost the country $3 million a day in lost tolls, fees and taxes, severely hampering the economy.

THAILAND: PLEDGE ON ANTIQUES -- Thailand said it would return 122 antique statues looted by smugglers from ancient temples in Cambodia and pledged to crack down on the trade. Foreign Minister Surin Pitsuwan made the announcement after a meeting in Phnom Penh with Prime Minister Hun Sen.
